candidates.title: Publish v0.9.0
candidates.body: Waiting for `soketto` to be published before we can publish this.

candidates.title: Reimplement the websocket transport.
candidates.body:
Actually two transports are implemented, one in the `framed` module whose output implements `Stream` and `Sink`, but not `AsyncRead` or `AsyncWrite`, and on top of that another transport which merely wraps the output of the former in a `RwStreamSink` to produce an output type which implements `AsyncRead` and `AsyncWrite`. The output of the `framed` transport produces and consumes just bytes which correspond to the actual application data in a websocket frame. (See https://github.com/libp2p/rust-libp2p/issues/1103 for details.)

The transport(s) now handle TLS, i.e. they use TLS for `/wss` multi-addresses (See https://github.com/libp2p/rust-libp2p/issues/1094 for details.)

I have created a version of the chat example to work with the websocket transport. If you want to try it you can find it here: https://gist.github.com/twittner/1c9ea9fcd538d5e6727cd6bb56c1a43d.

The transport uses the not yet published [soketto](https://github.com/paritytech/soketto) crate which is a heavily modified fork of the twist crate. If and when we agree to merge this PR soketto should be published to `crates.io` and the git reference in the `Cargo.toml` of `libp2p-websocket` should be replaced with a proper version number.

candidates.title: Add deflate protocol
candidates.body:
Add deflate protocol; fixes #955.

I hope I did this right, although I'm not 100% sure being so new to rust-libp2p and the surrounding ecosystem.

candidates.title: Update dependencies
candidates.body:
Based on https://deps.rs/repo/github/libp2p/rust-libp2p

This is technically a breaking change, because we expose `zeroize::Zeroize` in the API, but we're already in breaking-change land with #1117.

candidates.title: TCP transport: change listen address selection.
candidates.body:
Since every local socket address in the 127.0.0.0/8 space is looped back to 127.0.0.1/32 we should only have to report the later as the listen address. For other addresses we still attempt to discover host addresses when we encounter an unknown local address. We now also check that after
the host addresses have been reset that the address is now found, otherwise we produce an error.

candidates.title: Kademlia: Correct XOR metric.
candidates.body:
**Note**: Sits on top of https://github.com/libp2p/rust-libp2p/pull/1101.

This PR addresses what I believe to be two issues with the current implementation and use of Kademlia's XOR metric:

  1. The distance is currently equated with the bucket index, i.e. `distance(a,b) - 1` is the index of the bucket into which either peer is put by the other. The result is a metric that is not unidirectional, as defined in the Kademlia paper and, as far as I could see, as it is implemented in e.g. libp2p-go and libp2p-js (see e.g. [here](https://github.com/libp2p/go-libp2p-kbucket/blob/master/keyspace/xor.go#L21-L44)), which is to interpret the result of the XOR as-is as an integer representing the distance. The bucket index is of course still determined by the distance.

  2. The current `KBucketsPeerId` trait and its instances compute distances between types with differing bit lengths as well as between types that re-hash all inputs (i.e. `KadHash`) and "plain" `PeerId`s or `Multihash`es, or even just between `PeerId`s or `Multihash`es. Such distances are incorrect as per the libp2p spec requirement that all distances be computed over the XOR of the SHA256 hashes of the inputs, be it peer IDs, multihashes, etc. The computed distances can even fall outside of the image of the metric used for the `KBucketsTable` and thus fall in the range of a non-existent bucket. In the latter case, such distances are not currently used as a bucket index - they can only occur temporarily in the context of comparing distances for the purpose of sorting peers - but that still seems very undesirable.

These issues are addressed in this PR as follows:

  * Unidirectionality of the XOR metric is restored by keeping the "full" integer representation of the bitwise XOR. The result is an XOR metric as defined in the paper and as computed by other libp2p implementations. This should also open the door to avoiding the  "full table scan" when searching for the keys closest to a given key - the ideal order in which to visit the buckets can be computed with the help of the distance bit string, which is something I'd like to try afterwards.

  * As a simplification and to make it easy to "do the right thing", the XOR metric is only defined on an opaque `kbucket::Key` type, partially derived from the current `KadHash`. `KadHash` and `KBucketsPeerId` are removed.

These changes do not affect the distribution of keys into buckets, i.e. the same peer ID (as a former `KadHash`) still falls into the same bucket, but restoring unidirectionality means e.g. that lookups for the closest peers for a specific key from different nodes will now converge towards the same set of closest peers, as described in the paper.

Tests for the properties of the XOR metric have been added and some existing tests tweaked.

candidates.title: Allow a path for WS multiaddresses
candidates.body:
Adds the possibility to add a URL path to multiaddress that contain `ws` or `wss`.

I'm doing this as a draft because I don't really know what to do with the string representation of these. At the moment, outputting such an address works, but parsing it back will fail.
